topics.title: Reflection & Refraction (Snell's Law)
topics.summary: Laws of reflection (i=r) and refraction. Snell's law relates angles and refractive indices. Refractive index n=c/v. Frequency remains constant during refraction.

mcqs.question: Which statement correctly expresses the law of reflection?
Snell's law is written as:
options: n1 sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2
n1 cos θ1 = n2 cos θ2
mcqs.source_quote: n1 sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2

mcqs.question: The refractive index of a medium is defined as:
options: speed of light in vacuum divided by speed in medium

mcqs.question: If light passes from air (n ≈ 1.00) into glass (n ≈ 1.5), the refracted ray:
mcqs.source_quote: bends toward normal in denser medium

mcqs.question: Which quantity remains unchanged when light refracts across an interface?
The relationship between wavelength in vacuum (λ0), wavelength in medium (λ), and refractive index (n) is:
A ray incident at 30° in medium 1 (n1) emerges in medium 2 (n2) at 15°. Which is true if n2 > n1?
options: angle decreases when entering denser medium

mcqs.question: Which of the following is a correct effect of increasing refractive index of a medium?
At a boundary, the amplitude of transmitted light depends mainly on:
options: refractive indices and angle of incidence

mcqs.question: Which optical law is used to derive the path of least time (Fermat's principle) for refraction?

flashcards.front: State the law of reflection.
flashcards.back: Angle of incidence equals angle of reflection (i = r).

flashcards.front: Write Snell's law.
flashcards.back: n1 sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2.

flashcards.front: What is refractive index?
flashcards.back: n = c/v, ratio of speed of light in vacuum to speed in medium.

flashcards.front: Does frequency change during refraction?
flashcards.back: No — frequency stays same; wavelength and speed change.

flashcards.front: Relationship between λ (in medium) and λ0 (vacuum).
flashcards.back: λ = λ0 / n.

flashcards.front: Why does light bend toward normal when entering denser medium?
flashcards.back: Speed reduces in denser medium, changing direction per Snell's law.

flashcards.front: Define optical path length.
flashcards.back: Product of refractive index and geometric length; used in interference calculations.

flashcards.front: How are angles measured in reflection/refraction diagrams?
flashcards.back: Angles measured from the normal to the interface, not from surface.

topics.title: Total Internal Reflection & Fibre Optics
topics.summary: TIR occurs when light travels from denser to rarer medium at angle > critical angle. Optical fibers use repeated TIR for communication and endoscopy.

mcqs.question: Total internal reflection occurs when light tries to go from:
options: denser to rarer medium at angle > critical angle

mcqs.question: Critical angle is defined as the angle of incidence that produces:
For TIR to occur the refractive index of the first medium must be:
Optical fibers guide light by:
Single-mode fiber differs from multimode fiber by:
Which application commonly uses fiber optics?
The numerical aperture (NA) of a fiber relates to:
If the incident angle equals the critical angle, what is observed?

flashcards.front: Define critical angle.
flashcards.back: Minimum angle of incidence in denser medium at which refraction angle becomes 90°; beyond it TIR occurs.

flashcards.front: How do optical fibers confine light?
flashcards.back: By repeated total internal reflections between core and cladding with higher core index.

flashcards.front: State one major application of optical fibers.
flashcards.back: Medical endoscopes and long-distance communications.

flashcards.front: What happens to transmitted intensity as incidence approaches critical angle?
flashcards.back: Transmitted intensity decreases; energy increasingly reflected until TIR.

flashcards.front: How does numerical aperture affect fiber coupling?
flashcards.back: Higher NA accepts larger input cone of light; easier coupling.

flashcards.front: Why must core and cladding indices differ?
flashcards.back: To ensure TIR inside core; core index > cladding index.

topics.title: Nature of Light & Theories
topics.summary: Historical theories: Newton's corpuscular (particles), Huygens' wave (wavefronts), Maxwell's electromagnetic, and Planck's quantum theory.

mcqs.question: Which theory treated light as particles?
Huygens' principle explains:
Maxwell unified electricity and magnetism and predicted that light is:
Planck introduced quantization to solve which problem?
Which concept is central to Einstein's photoelectric explanation?
Which observation forced particle-like description of light?

flashcards.front: Summarize Huygens' principle.
flashcards.back: Every point on a wavefront acts as a source of secondary spherical wavelets; new wavefront is envelope of these wavelets.

flashcards.front: What did Maxwell show about light?
flashcards.back: Light is an electromagnetic wave; electric and magnetic fields oscillate perpendicular to direction of propagation.

flashcards.front: Planck's key postulate.
flashcards.back: Energy exchange in oscillators is quantized: E = nhν (n integer).

flashcards.front: Why was Einstein important for light theory?
flashcards.back: He proposed photons—quantized light packets—explaining the photoelectric effect (E = hν).

topics.title: Interference (Young's Double Slit)
topics.summary: Interference is superposition of waves. Constructive (bright) at path difference = mλ, destructive (dark) at (m+½)λ. Requires coherent sources.

Destructive interference occurs when path difference =
In Young's double-slit experiment, fringe spacing on screen depends on:
options: wavelength, slit separation, and screen distance

mcqs.question: Coherent sources mean:
options: constant phase difference and same frequency

mcqs.question: If wavelength increases, fringe separation:
Bright fringes correspond to:
Which of these reduces fringe visibility?
For small angle approximation, fringe spacing y ≈ (Dλ)/d, where D is screen distance, d slit separation. Which variable in denominator reduces spacing?
Double-slit works poorly with incoherent sources because:
What produces the central bright fringe position?
options: equal path from two slits (zero path difference)

mcqs.question: If two sources have frequency mismatch, interference pattern:
The intensity of interference fringes depends on amplitude and phase; maximum intensity when:

flashcards.front: What is path difference for constructive interference?
flashcards.back: Any integer multiple of wavelength: Δ = mλ.

flashcards.front: Define coherence.
flashcards.back: Constant phase relationship and same frequency over time between sources.

flashcards.front: Formula for fringe spacing in double-slit (small angle).
flashcards.back: y = Dλ/d (approx), where D = screen distance, d = slit separation.

flashcards.front: Why does using white light produce multiple colored fringes?
flashcards.back: Different wavelengths produce different fringe separations; colors separate spatially.

flashcards.front: What reduces visibility of fringes?
flashcards.back: Incoherence, unequal amplitudes, spectral width, or misalignment.

flashcards.front: Central maximum condition.
flashcards.back: Zero path difference between the two slits (m = 0).

flashcards.front: How to get sharper fringes?
flashcards.back: Increase coherence and monochromaticity; increase D/d ratio.

flashcards.front: Effect of slit width on fringe visibility.
flashcards.back: Wider slits increase diffraction envelope; may reduce fringe contrast.

topics.title: Diffraction & Diffraction Grating
topics.summary: Diffraction is bending of light around obstacles. Fraunhofer (far-field) vs Fresnel (near-field). Gratings: d sin θ = nλ for spectral analysis.

mcqs.question: Fraunhofer diffraction is observed when:
options: source and screen are effectively at infinite distance (parallel rays)

mcqs.question: The grating equation is:
Higher order maxima in a grating correspond to:
options: larger values of n in d sin θ = nλ

mcqs.question: Diffraction causes:
options: spreading of waves when passing through apertures

mcqs.question: Which is true of Fresnel diffraction?
Resolving power of a grating increases with:
If slit width is comparable to wavelength, diffraction:
A transmission grating disperses light because:
options: each slit produces waves that interfere at different angles by wavelength

flashcards.front: Grating equation.
flashcards.back: d sin θ = nλ; d = grating spacing, n = order.

flashcards.front: Fraunhofer vs Fresnel.
flashcards.back: Fraunhofer = far-field (parallel rays), Fresnel = near-field (curved wavefronts).

flashcards.front: What increases spectral resolution in a grating?
flashcards.back: More illuminated slits (larger N) and higher order.

flashcards.front: When does single-slit diffraction produce central maximum only?
flashcards.back: When slit width is comparable to wavelength, central maximum dominates and side maxima are faint.

flashcards.front: Why do diffraction patterns depend on aperture shape?
flashcards.back: Pattern is Fourier transform of aperture function; shape controls intensity distribution.

flashcards.front: Use of diffraction gratings.
flashcards.back: Spectral analysis, wavelength measurement, monochromators.

topics.title: Polarization
topics.summary: Polarization restricts light vibrations to a plane. Polaroids transmit one component. Applications: Brewster angle, wave plates.

mcqs.question: Plane polarized light has:
options: electric field oscillating in a single plane

mcqs.question: Polaroid sheets work by:
When unpolarized light passes through two ideal polarizers at 90°, transmitted intensity is:
Brewster's angle is associated with:
Circularly polarized light:
options: has E vector rotating with constant magnitude

mcqs.question: A quarter-wave plate is used to:
options: convert linear to circular polarization (and vice versa)

flashcards.front: Define plane polarized light.
flashcards.back: Light whose E-field oscillates in one fixed plane perpendicular to direction of travel.

flashcards.front: How does a polaroid sheet polarize light?
flashcards.back: It transmits one component of electric vibration and absorbs the orthogonal component.

flashcards.front: What is Brewster's angle condition?
flashcards.back: Angle where reflected light is fully polarized; tan θB = n2/n1.

flashcards.front: Purpose of quarter-wave plate.
flashcards.back: Introduce 90° phase shift between orthogonal components, producing circular or elliptical polarization.

flashcards.front: How to extinguish light with polarizers?
flashcards.back: Place two linear polarizers crossed at 90°; transmitted intensity tends to zero.

topics.title: Photoelectric Effect & Photocell
topics.summary: Emission of electrons when light hits metal. Einstein's equation: K_max = hν − Φ. Key: threshold frequency, work function, stopping potential.

mcqs.question: Einstein's photoelectric equation is:
Threshold frequency (ν0) is:
options: minimum frequency required to emit electrons

mcqs.question: Which factor does NOT affect maximum kinetic energy of photoelectrons?
Increasing light intensity at frequency above threshold causes:
Stopping potential is used to:
options: measure maximum kinetic energy of emitted electrons

mcqs.question: If incident frequency is below threshold, photoemission:
options: does not occur regardless of intensity

mcqs.question: Work function Φ is:
options: minimum energy needed to free an electron

mcqs.question: Photoelectric effect confirmed particle nature of light because:
options: KE depends on frequency not intensity

mcqs.question: In a photocell, increasing anode potential (positive) results in:
Graph of KE vs frequency is linear with slope equal to:
If stopping potential increases, maximum KE of electrons:
What would double the photocurrent for ν > ν0 (keeping other factors constant)?

flashcards.front: State Einstein's photoelectric equation.
flashcards.back: K_max = hν − Φ, where Φ is work function.

flashcards.front: Define work function.
flashcards.back: Minimum energy to remove an electron from metal surface (material-specific).

flashcards.front: What is threshold frequency?
flashcards.back: ν0 = Φ/h; minimum frequency needed to eject electrons.

flashcards.front: How does intensity affect photoelectric emission?
flashcards.back: For ν > ν0, intensity increases electron emission rate (current), not KE.

flashcards.front: How to measure maximum kinetic energy of photoelectrons?
flashcards.back: Use stopping potential V0: eV0 = K_max.

flashcards.front: Why photoelectric effect contradicts classical wave theory?
flashcards.back: Classical expected KE to rise with intensity; experiments showed KE depends on frequency only.

flashcards.front: How is Planck's constant observed in photoelectric experiments?
flashcards.back: Slope of K_max vs ν graph equals h.

flashcards.front: What is stopping potential?
flashcards.back: Minimum reverse potential to stop photoelectrons from reaching anode; relates to max KE.

flashcards.front: Photocell working principle in one line.
flashcards.back: Photoemission from cathode; emitted electrons collected at anode producing current proportional to photon flux.

flashcards.front: How to increase sensitivity of a photocell?
flashcards.back: Use low-work-function cathode, increase collection efficiency, and reduce dark current.

topics.summary: Cross-topic questions covering wave-particle duality, thin films, gratings, applications, and general optics principles.

flashcards.front: What is fringe visibility?
flashcards.back: Measure of contrast between bright and dark fringes; (I_max − I_min)/(I_max + I_min).

flashcards.front: Definition of coherence length.
flashcards.back: Length over which light maintains predictable phase relation; related to spectral width.

flashcards.front: Use of optical fibers in communications.
flashcards.back: Low-loss, high-bandwidth transmission via TIR in core with cladding.

flashcards.front: Why does KE not depend on intensity in photoelectric effect?
flashcards.back: Each photon has energy hν; intensity only changes photon flux, not energy per photon.

flashcards.front: Practical test for polarization.
flashcards.back: Rotating a linear polarizer in front of polarized light changes intensity as cos^2(θ).

flashcards.front: What is numerical aperture (NA)?
flashcards.back: Measure of light acceptance cone of a fiber; NA = n0 sin θ_accept.

flashcards.front: Quick tip to identify interference vs diffraction experiment.
flashcards.back: Interference uses few coherent sources (slits); diffraction emphasizes aperture shape and single-slit patterns.
